name: Monteprama Archer n.5 (Prexiau)
info:
One of the statues from the Mont'e Prama collection, which includes 25 life-size human figures, depicting archers, boxers and warriors, and 13 building models representing typical Nuragic towers. This statue is one of the best preserved items representing an archer (Archer n.5 - Prexiau). It has been acquired using a combination of laser scanning and flash photography to recover shape and albedo of complete 3D models. The fixed view used in the annotated model visualization has been chosen to display a set of important features from the CH point of view, and has been resampled at the resolution of approximately 0.25mm/pixel. In this view, it is possible to see the quiver (with the resin box and the small sword), and the left arm, which holds the bow. Activate the "Annotations" mode to see more visual and textual information.

Courtesy of CRBC Sassari.

infos:
Sculpting techniques

Several different tools and sculpting techniques have been used to render the archer's fist, which is protected by a decorated glove, and the left arm, which is almost entirely covered by an armguard.

Peter Rockwell, Le tecniche antiche In: Le sculture di Mont’e Prama–Conservazione e restauro 2014, Gangemi editore, pp. 353-360

Distinctive archer's elements

Five element of the statue are highlighted, i.e., the quiver, the armguard, the remaining part of the bow, the archer's glove, and a reinforcement part that connects the bow and the left arm.

Bow reconstruction hypothesis

The archer's bow has not been entirely preserved (only the lowest part is visible in the statue). The annotation aims at depicting a hypothesis of reconstruction of the missing bow. It should have lied on the archer shoulder, and the presence of a tight bowstring remains in some details in the back of the statue.
